description: Borrowed from Latin terminātus, past participle of terminō (“I set bounds to, bound, limit, end, close, terminate”), from terminus (“a bound, limit, end”); see term, terminus. Doublet of termine.

adjectives.description: terminate (comparative more terminate, superlative most terminate)

entries.meaning: Having a definite and clear limit or boundary; having a determinate size, shape or magnitude.
examples: Mountains on the Moon cast shadows that are very dark, terminate and more distinct than those cast by mountains on the Earth.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) Expressible in a finite number of terms; (of a decimal) not recurring or infinite.
examples: One third is a recurring decimal, but one half is a terminate decimal.

verbs.description: terminate (third-person singular simple present terminates, present participle terminating, simple past and past participle terminated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To end something, especially when left in an incomplete state.
examples: to terminate a process before its completion
to terminate an effort, or a controversy

entries.meaning: (transitive) To set or be a limit or boundary to.
examples: to terminate a surface by a line

entries.meaning: (transitive, euphemistic) To kill someone or something.
examples: The enemy must be terminated by any means possible.

entries.meaning: (transitive, euphemistic) To end the employment contract of an employee; to fire, lay off.
(intransitive) To end, conclude, or cease; to come to an end.
(intransitive) Of a mode of transport, to end its journey; or, of a railway line, to reach its terminus.
examples: This train terminates at the next station.
